005
006package gov.nist.secauto.metaschema.core.datatype.object;
007
008import gov.nist.secauto.metaschema.core.datatype.AbstractCustomJavaDataType;
009
010import java.time.ZonedDateTime;
011
012import edu.umd.cs.findbugs.annotations.NonNull;
013
014/**
015 * Metaschema has a need to represent dates and times that allow for an
016 * ambiguous time zone. This is due to some models not requiring a time zone as
017 * part of a date/time. An ambiguous dateTime allows a time zone to be inferred,
018 * without change information in the source content.
019 * <p>
020 * This class wraps a ZonedDateTime object and tracks if a time zone was found
021 * when parsing, which can be used to ensure that the assumed time zone is not
022 * written back out in such cases.
023 *
024 * @param <TYPE>
025 *          the bound object type
026 */
027public abstract class AbstractAmbiguousTemporal<TYPE extends AbstractAmbiguousTemporal<TYPE>>
028    extends AbstractCustomJavaDataType<TYPE, ZonedDateTime> {
029  private final boolean timeZone;
030
031  /**
032   * Construct a new object. This type supports ambiguous dates/times that were
033   * provided without a time zone.
034   *
035   * @param value
036   *          the date value
037   * @param hasTimeZone
038   *          {@code true} if the date is intended to have an associated time zone
039   *          or {@code false} otherwise
040   */
041  public AbstractAmbiguousTemporal(@NonNull ZonedDateTime value, boolean hasTimeZone) {
042    super(value);
043    this.timeZone = hasTimeZone;
044  }
045
046  /**
047   * Indicate if a time zone is configured.
048   *
049   * @return {@code true} if the date is intended to have an associated time zone
050   *         or {@code false} otherwise
051   */
052  public boolean hasTimeZone() {
053    return timeZone;
054  }
055}
